title: Powering a blog with Notion and Netlify
Description: How I moved my blog from Digital Ocean to Netlify and how I use Notion for writing my blog.

inline_content.Text: Description: How I moved my blog from Digital Ocean to Netlify and how I use Notion for writing my blog.

title: The last iteration of this blog was a Go program running on
Digital Ocean
a
https://www.digitalocean.com/
's cheapest VM ($5/month).

inline_content.Text: The last iteration of this blog was a Go program running on
Digital Ocean
's cheapest VM ($5/month).
Recently I've made 2 big changes:

title: I converted it to a static site hosted on
Netlify
a
https://www.netlify.com/

inline_content.Text: I converted it to a static site hosted on
Netlify

title: I used
Notion
a
https://notion.so
for writing the posts instead of writing markdown files in a text editor

inline_content.Text: I used
Notion
for writing the posts instead of writing markdown files in a text editor
Moving to Netlify

title: My blog was effectively a static website. It didn't need a backend so writing a custom server and running it on a VPS was overkill.

inline_content.Text: My blog was effectively a static website. It didn't need a backend so writing a custom server and running it on a VPS was overkill.

title: Few months back Netlify reduced the price of their cheapest plan to $0 (from $10/month).

inline_content.Text: Few months back Netlify reduced the price of their cheapest plan to $0 (from $10/month).

title: I'm always looking to simplify and cheapify my life so I bit the bullet  and converted my custom server to generate static HTML files suitable for hosting on Netlify.

inline_content.Text: I'm always looking to simplify and cheapify my life so I bit the bullet  and converted my custom server to generate static HTML files suitable for hosting on Netlify.

title: If you want to publish a static website and are starting from scratch, the best approach is to use one of the many static site generators (e.g. Hugo or Jekyll).

inline_content.Text: If you want to publish a static website and are starting from scratch, the best approach is to use one of the many static site generators (e.g. Hugo or Jekyll).

title: I already had a lot of content in .html and markdown files accumulated over the years and code to generate the website for serving from custom web server so I refactored to code to generate static HTML instead.

inline_content.Text: I already had a lot of content in .html and markdown files accumulated over the years and code to generate the website for serving from custom web server so I refactored to code to generate static HTML instead.

title: Refactoring process was time consuming but simple.

inline_content.Text: Refactoring process was time consuming but simple.

title: For dynamically generated html I changed the code to generate a .html file and setup appropriate url => file mapping using
_redirect
c
file.

inline_content.Text: For dynamically generated html I changed the code to generate a .html file and setup appropriate url => file mapping using
_redirect
file.

title: For local testing I use
Caddy
a
https://caddyserver.com/
and generate
Caddyfile
c
with appropriate redirects. There are minor differences when testing locally because there are semantic differences between redirect capabilities of Netlify and Caddy but it's good enough.

inline_content.Text: For local testing I use
Caddy
and generate
Caddyfile
with appropriate redirects. There are minor differences when testing locally because there are semantic differences between redirect capabilities of Netlify and Caddy but it's good enough.

title: Netlify also has an option to do a draft deploy under a unique URL. This is good for previewing the changes before publishing.

inline_content.Text: Netlify also has an option to do a draft deploy under a unique URL. This is good for previewing the changes before publishing.

title: At the end of code refactoring I effectively ended up with a custom static site generator.

inline_content.Text: At the end of code refactoring I effectively ended up with a custom static site generator.
The verdict
I'm happy with the result.

title: Netlify has all the features I care about for a basic website.

inline_content.Text: Netlify has all the features I care about for a basic website.

title: Notably they provide free SSL with Let's Encrypt, allow custom domains and have capable redirect capabilities. They use CDN so should be faster than hosting on a single host.

inline_content.Text: Notably they provide free SSL with Let's Encrypt, allow custom domains and have capable redirect capabilities. They use CDN so should be faster than hosting on a single host.

title: The only thing I miss is being able to see analytics for 404. With my own server I was logging all requests for pages that don't exist on my server. Many of them were bots trying to hack me via known vulnerabilities in popular software like WordPress but sometimes it would be caused by my mistake or a request for a valid article incorrectly linked. Seeing those I was able to fix most of them by adding redirects.

inline_content.Text: The only thing I miss is being able to see analytics for 404. With my own server I was logging all requests for pages that don't exist on my server. Many of them were bots trying to hack me via known vulnerabilities in popular software like WordPress but sometimes it would be caused by my mistake or a request for a valid article incorrectly linked. Seeing those I was able to fix most of them by adding redirects.

title: I hope Netlify can sustain their generous free plan.

inline_content.Text: I hope Netlify can sustain their generous free plan.

title: Luckily there are plenty of options to host a static website so even if Netlify goes under, it'll be easy to move somewhere else, like
Firebase Hosting
a
https://firebase.google.com/docs/hosting/
surge.sh
a
http://surge.sh/
GitHub pages
a
https://pages.github.com/
GitLab pages
a
https://about.gitlab.com/features/pages/
and
many others
a
https://www.notion.so/c674bebe8adf44d18c3a36cc18c131e2

inline_content.Text: Luckily there are plenty of options to host a static website so even if Netlify goes under, it'll be easy to move somewhere else, like
Firebase Hosting
surge.sh
GitHub pages
GitLab pages
and
many others

title: Using Notion as Content Management System

inline_content.Text: Using Notion as Content Management System

title: The easier it is to write, the more I write.

inline_content.Text: The easier it is to write, the more I write.

title: I failed the "as easy as possible" part.

inline_content.Text: I failed the "as easy as possible" part.

title: In absolute terms, creating a new markdown file and writing a post doesn't take much time.

inline_content.Text: In absolute terms, creating a new markdown file and writing a post doesn't take much time.

title: In practice it's enough friction to deter me from writing. In my worst year I only wrote 1 new blog post.

inline_content.Text: In practice it's enough friction to deter me from writing. In my worst year I only wrote 1 new blog post.

title: fIn a perfect world I would open an app and start writing. When I'm done writing I would publish with a click of a button.

inline_content.Text: fIn a perfect world I would open an app and start writing. When I'm done writing I would publish with a click of a button.
Enter Notion

title: Notion
a
https://www.notion.so/
is as close to a perfect writing tool as it gets: open a page and start writing.

inline_content.Text: Notion
is as close to a perfect writing tool as it gets: open a page and start writing.

title: The problem is: all that content is trapped in Notion. You can publish (publicly share) a page but I want more flexibility:

inline_content.Text: The problem is: all that content is trapped in Notion. You can publish (publicly share) a page but I want more flexibility:

title: I want to host on my own domain; my website is partly a tool for marketing myself

inline_content.Text: I want to host on my own domain; my website is partly a tool for marketing myself

title: I want integration with Google Analytics

inline_content.Text: I want integration with Google Analytics
I want a custom design

title: I want to provide rss feed

inline_content.Text: I want to provide rss feed

title: Thankfully I'm a programmer: if something can be done with software, I can do it.

inline_content.Text: Thankfully I'm a programmer: if something can be done with software, I can do it.

title: I started a one-man Notion Liberation Front. My goal: liberate content trapped inside Notion.

inline_content.Text: I started a one-man Notion Liberation Front. My goal: liberate content trapped inside Notion.

title: I
reverse-engineered their API
a
https://www.notion.so/How-I-reverse-engineered-Notion-API-88aee8f43620471aa9dbcad28368174c
, wrote a
Go library
a
https://github.com/kjk/notionapi
and after another round of code refactoring I had my blog powered by Notion thanks to this
Go program
a
https://github.com/kjk/blog

inline_content.Text: I
reverse-engineered their API
, wrote a
Go library
and after another round of code refactoring I had my blog powered by Notion thanks to this
Go program

title: I imported my old blog posts into Notion. They have a decent markdown importer although I did have to do some cleaning up.

inline_content.Text: I imported my old blog posts into Notion. They have a decent markdown importer although I did have to do some cleaning up.

title: I went even further and published most of my notes to my website as well. I still have many private notes in Notion but most of them can be just as well be publicly visible.

inline_content.Text: I went even further and published most of my notes to my website as well. I still have many private notes in Notion but most of them can be just as well be publicly visible.

title: There's no way I could do publish so much content without Notion.

inline_content.Text: There's no way I could do publish so much content without Notion.

title: I also automated publishing by using cron functionality in
Travis CI
a
https://travis-ci.org/
. Every day a script downloads latest content from Notion, caches it in git repository and re-generates a website.

inline_content.Text: I also automated publishing by using cron functionality in
Travis CI
. Every day a script downloads latest content from Notion, caches it in git repository and re-generates a website.

title: Everything now runs on auto-pilot. I can just write new articles in Notion and my website will be automatically updated every day.

inline_content.Text: Everything now runs on auto-pilot. I can just write new articles in Notion and my website will be automatically updated every day.

Root.title: Powering a blog with Notion and Netlify
